s.text: But it's true.

The glow of that happy discovery can last for years, as Nathan Myrhvold explained and simultaneously demonstrated in a recent Slate "." These are folks lucky enough to be able to choose their careers and to have a good shot at success at whatever they choose.

Everybody is trying to do the same thing; some succeed, and those who don't are envious.

Everybody is trying to do the same thing; some succeed, and those who don't are envious.

Even in New York, where money matters more, there are (unlike in Washington) strong independent subcultures in which a journalist or college professor or unemployed actor can take comfort in an independent value system.

What seems to have struck the East Coast only recently is that the Internet is making a smaller subset of all humankind--people who start Internet-related companies or join them before they go public--incredibly wealthy.
But the smart kids tend to win in adult life.
But the smart kids tend to win in adult life.
But the smart kids tend to win in adult life.
But the smart kids tend to win in adult life.
(And, poor souls, these investment bankers generally cannot find comfort in an independent value system.)

At the crucial moment when they make their choices, many of these people honestly believe that money--beyond the cost of upper-middle-class comfort--is not all that important to them, and most of them may turn out to be right.

Sometimes this personal process of maturity or decay (take your pick) is reinforced by what's happening in the culture.

And the people at the top of those heaps, earning plenty to live comfortably, honestly wouldn't trade being, say, curator of dinosaurs at the Museum of Natural History for being just another multimillionaire investment banker.

Actually, a graph of the changing value of money in the status market would look a lot like a graph of the Dow Jones industrial average: It rose steadily starting about 1982--the year a star New York Times reporter shocked his journalist colleagues by quitting the Times to become an investment banker--crested and sank briefly in the late 1980s, quickly recovered, and has been hitting new heights ever since.

Price-earnings ratios are perilously high in both.
